subject: RE: [junit] Don't show exception messages to users (was assertTrue(true))
msgSnippet: ... We have to translate every exception, which is quite a lot of work. In my experience only very few of our exceptions make sense to translate them. An
messageBody:
--- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > > Of course error messages should be localized.
> These are shown to the
> > > end user and are part of the user interface,
> just like menu items,
> > > window titles, and other parts of the user
> interface. However,
> > > exception detail messages make extremely poor
> error messages.

We have to translate every exception, which is quite a
lot of work.

In my experience only very few of our exceptions make
sense to translate them.

An example for a exception which should be translated
is MeanwhileChangedException. It is raised if there is
a conflict in persisting data by different users, much
like a CVS conflict. Believe it or not, in 999 of 1000
cases, the exception is not thrown because another
user has changed the data but because of ones own
programming bugs.

At least exceptions, which are subclassed of
RuntimeException need not to be translated, since they
are a kind of SystemException and no
ApplicationExceptions. This kind of exception would
help no user but only the programmers.

I think that the majority of exceptions will not be
useful to read for the users, even if they are
translated.

It creates a lot of overhead to use exception keys,
unique exception numbers, exception message templates
with placeholders, exception constructors with
parameters to fill the placeholders, and of course the
work needed for the translation of all these messages.

Maybe it is better to leave all exceptions without
translation support. I think it is easier to integrate
the messages and translation in a layer above the
exceptions. As I said, only a small percentage of all
exceptions and exception messages is useful for a user.
